  • Plaintiffs claim NuScale understated the risks tied to ENTRA1, as fresh details emerge about substantial payments and project delays.
  • At the same time, NuScale received approval for a small modular reactor project in Romania and major shareholder Fluor announced plans to exit its position.

NuScale Power, trading at $13.33, is facing a sharp swing in sentiment, with the share price down 8.9% over the past week and 30.6% over the past month. Returns are also weaker year to date at 18.3% and over the past year at 20.2%, despite a gain of 33.3% over three years and 32.6% over five years. For investors, that mix of longer term gains and recent pressure highlights the current legal and corporate headlines in a very direct way.

The combination of securities lawsuits, questions around ENTRA1, the Romanian project approval, and Fluor's planned exit presents several factors to consider. How NuScale responds to the legal claims, discloses partner relationships and manages funding for future projects could be central to how risk and sentiment evolve from here.

The lawsuits around ENTRA1 hit the core of how NuScale plans to turn its Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved small modular reactor design into actual projects. Plaintiffs claim NuScale entrusted commercialization and large capital commitments to a partner with no meaningful nuclear track record, while paying ENTRA1 about US$495 million tied to the Tennessee Valley Authority agreement. That sits next to a full year 2025 net loss of US$355.79 million on sales of US$31.48 million and a new US$1b at the market equity offering filing, so legal uncertainty is landing at the same time as heavy cash usage and potential dilution. The recent Romanian approval shows the technology is still finding willing counterparties, but Fluor’s intention to exit and multiple law firms pursuing securities cases add questions around governance and disclosure. For you as an investor, the key issue is whether project partners, regulators and capital providers remain comfortable backing NuScale while these claims work through the courts, which can take years and could involve settlements, higher costs or tighter oversight.

  • The ENTRA1 focused lawsuits directly challenge the narrative’s reliance on that partner to drive commercialization and funding, and highlight that this dependency could be a key execution weak point.
  • The size and structure of the ENTRA1 payments, along with the follow on US$1b equity filing, may not be fully captured in earlier narrative assumptions about funding sources and cash runway.

Second, NuScale’s cash burn, use of the US$1b equity program and any changes in project timing in future results, as the company reported a full year 2025 net loss of US$355.79 million. Third, progress on concrete delivery milestones at the Romanian plant and with the TVA partnership compared with other SMR efforts from players such as Rolls Royce and GE Hitachi. Together, those signals will indicate whether NuScale can keep moving from engineering work to funded projects while managing legal and financing pressures.
